Fig. 1 Catalytic performance of supported palladium catalysts(a) Pd/OMS-2; (b) Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3; (c) Pd/Pb-OMS-2. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of fresh and used supported palladium catalysts (a) fresh Pd/OMS-2; (b) used Pd/OMS-2; (c) fresh Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (d) used Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (e) fresh Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3; (f) used Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 HRTEM images of fresh and used supported palladium catalysts (a) fresh Pd/OMS-2; (b) used Pd/OMS-2; (c) fresh Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (d) used Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (e) fresh Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3; (f) used Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Pd3d XPS spectra of fresh and used supported palladium catalysts. (a) fresh Pd/OMS-2; (b) used Pd/OMS-2; (c) fresh Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (d) used Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (e) fresh Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3; (f) used Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of Pd/OMS-2 catalyst (a) fresh Pd/OMS-2 calcinated at 300°Cfor 4h; (b) fresh Pd/OMS-2 calcinated at 300°C for 8h; (c) fresh Pd/OMS-2 calcinated at 300°C for 20h; (d) fresh Pd/OMS-2 calcinated at 400°C for 4h; (e) used Pd/OMS-2 catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 H2-TPR profiles of fresh and used supported palladium catalysts. (a) fresh Pd/OMS-2; (b) used Pd/OMS-2; (c) fresh Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (d) used Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (e) fresh Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3; (f) used Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 O1s XPS spectra of the fresh and used supported palladium catalysts. (a) fresh Pd/OMS-2; (b) used Pd/OMS-2; (c) fresh Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (d) used Pd/Pb-OMS-2; (e) fresh Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3; (f) used Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3. Fig. 7 Table 1 Palladium contents of fresh and used supported catalysts. Deactivation causes of supported palladium catalysts for the oxidative carbonylation of phenol Chaofan Yin a Jie Zhou a Qiming Chen a Jinyu Han b Yuanxin Wu a b Xiaojun Yang a ⁎ a Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Process of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering & Pharmacy, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan 430073, PR China Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Process of Ministry of Education School of Chemical Engineering & Pharmacy Wuhan Institute of Technology Wuhan 430073 PR China b School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, PR China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Palladium catalysts supported on manganese oxides octahedral molecular sieves (OMS-2), Pb doped OMS-2 (Pb-OMS-2) and perovskite-type La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 were prepared for investigating the deactivation causes of catalysts during the oxidative carbonylation of phenol. The catalytic experiments on three different sets of catalysts demonstrated that they were inactive after continuous reaction for 22h. XRD patterns and HRTEM images demonstrated that carbonaceous pollution and palladium leaching occurred during the reaction process. The solvent and oxygen have significant impact on the palladium leaching by ICP-AES analysis. In addition, hot filtration tests and SH-HZSM-5 adsorption studies indicated that the leached palladium species are not active species. The results of XPS patterns and H2-TPR profiles showed that aggregation and reduction of Pd species was another deactivation cause. It was discovered that lattice oxygen species decreased and palladium aggregated, which hindered the re-oxidation of Pd(0) to Pd(II). In summary, carbonaceous pollution, Pd leaching, aggregation and consumption of oxygen species hindered the redox recycling of palladium, which resulted in the deactivation of supported palladium catalysts for the oxidative carbonylation of phenol. Keywords Diphenyl carbonate Oxidative carbonylation Deactivation causes Pd leaching Oxygen species 1 Introduction Palladium-catalyzed oxidative carbonylation reaction has become a novel and powerful tool for diphenyl carbonate (DPC) synthesis [1,2]. The process of oxidative carbonylation has several advantages over the traditional phosgene process as the latter comprises the use of toxic and corrosive reagents. The process of oxidative carbonylation is environmentally-friendly and utilizes easily available raw materials with molecular oxygen as the oxidant. Many efforts were made to develop a high-performance catalyst for the oxidative carbonylation reaction which could be easily separated and repeatedly used. It is generally accepted that palladium is active species and its catalytic performance is better than the other metal catalysts [3,4]. At the previous stage, homogenous palladium catalysts were referred and PdCl2, Pd(OAC)2, or Pd(acac)2 were common homogeneous catalysts. Because the ligands are beneficial to cis-reaction between phenol and CO, the Pd-carbene complex with bis(heterocyclic carbene) ligands and Pd-2,2′-bipyridyl complex with 2,2′-bipyridyl ligands were prepared and became another kind of high efficient homogeneous catalysts. Homogeneous catalysts have not been commercialized because of one major disadvantage compared with heterogeneous catalysts: the difficulty encountered when trying to separate the catalyst from reaction product or solvent. In recent years, heterogeneous palladium catalysts turn into mainstream according to the reported literature. A number of heterogeneous palladium catalysts anchored on supports including activated carbon, polystyrene, silicon dioxide, layered double hydroxides, organic-inorganic hybrid materials and mixed metal oxides were investigated [5]. A number of homogeneous or heterogeneous palladium catalysts were reported to be effective, but catalyst deactivation has not been addressed in detail until now [5–11]. Among the several catalyst deactivation causes described in the literature, five main causes of deactivation are poisoning, fouling, thermal degradation initiated by high temperature, mechanical damage, and corrosion/leaching by the reaction mixture. In palladium-catalyzed oxidative carbonylation of phenol, the deactivation of palladium catalysts is generally attributed to the reduction and aggregation of the active center Pd(II) to Pd(0). The formation of metallic Pd nanoparticles in significant amount occurred with homogeneous palladium systems [10,12],which indicated that Pd(II)transformed into Pd(0) in the reaction and led to catalyst deactivation. Song [13] observes the peak representing metallic Pd in XRD patterns of carbon-supported palladium catalyst and speculated that metallic Pd catalyst was readily sintered in an enriched reducing CO atmosphere. He even considered that zero-valent palladium particles were an active species. Leaching is another deactivation cause to be considered [14]. The leached compounds rather than the solid phase maybe the actual active species. Takagi [15] reports that soluble Pd existed in Pd/C-PbO catalytic system. Pd leaching was also observed in the system containing acetate salts, but the activity of PdCl2-OIH(organic–inorganic hybrid) catalysts remained virtually unchanged when the catalyst was recycled and reused [16]. Unlike PdCl2-OIH catalysts, on account of Pd leaching and destruction of the tubular structure, the activity of the Pd-O/CeO2-nanotube catalyst decreased substantially when the catalyst was recycled and reused [17]. Our research group has always placed emphasis on the enhanced activity of Pb-doped supported palladium catalysts in oxidative carbonylation of phenol [18]. Nevertheless, the importance of catalyst stability is often underestimated. Therefore, a better understanding of deactivation causes is essential for improving and optimizing the performance of palladium catalysts, and several measures were taken to evaluate the deactivation behavior of catalyst. Herein, deactivation causes for supported palladium catalysts were studied, and some fundamental conclusions were obtained. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Three sets of oxide supports were obtained as suggested in literature. Manganese oxide octahedral molecular sieves(abbreviated as K-OMS-2) supports were synthesized by the reflux method. Lead doped OMS-2 supports(labeled as Pb-OMS-2) were prepared by an impregnation method. The K-OMS-2 was impregnated with a suitable volume of Pb(NO3)2 solution and then dried at 70°C under vacuum. Perovskite-type La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 supports were obtained by a sol-gel method, using metal nitrates and citric acid as starting materials in stoichiometric amounts. Reagents of KMnO4 (99.0%), MnSO4·H2O (99.0%), La(NO3)3·nH2O(La2O3 ≥44%), Pb(NO3)2 (99.0%), Mn(NO3)2 solution(60%), citric acid (98.0%), nitric acid (AR, 60%) were used as starting materials purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. K-OMS-2 was prepared by a reflux method according to the literature [19]. To a 500ml of round-bottomed flask with a condenser, potassium permanganate solution (0.4M, 225ml) was added to a mixture of manganese sulfate hydrate solution (1.75M, 67.5ml) and concentrated nitric acid (6.8ml). The dark brown slurry was refluxed for 24h, then filtered and washed with deionized water for several times. The K-OMS-2 was dried at 120°C overnight before use. To prepare Pb-OMS-2, 7.000g K-OMS-2 prepared by the reflux method was impregnated with 70.0ml of Pb(NO3)2 aqueous solutions with different concentrations. And then the mixture was stirred for 24h, followed by evaporation. Pb-OMS-2 were obtained by calcination in a muffle furnace at 450°C for 6h [18]. The Perovskite-type La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 supports were obtained by a sol-gel method, using metal nitrates and citric acid as starting materials with nominal atomic ratios. Then, the aqueous solutions of metal nitrates with nominal atomic ratios La: Pb: Mn=0.5:0.5:1 were mixed together in deionized water. Citric acid(CA) was proportionally added to the metal solution to have the same amounts of equivalents. Then, the solution was concentrated by evaporation at approximately 50°C with stirring for 1h to convert them to stable (La, Mn)/CA complexes. The solution, while being stirred, heated at approximately 75°C to remove excess water. During the evaporation, reddish-brown gases corresponding to NXOY removed from the solution and a viscous and bubbly mass was produced upon cooling. Then, the dry gel was obtained by letting the sol into an oven and heated slowly to 120°C. The gel pieces were ground to form a fine powder. Finally, La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 nanoparticles were gained by thermal treatment of the precursor at 650°C for 9h in air [20]. 0.42g PdCl2 was dissolved in 50.0ml aqueous solution when the pH value was adjusted to 1.0 with concentrated hydrochloric acid. K-OMS-2, Pb-OMS-2 and La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 supports were dipped into the PdCl2 solution, respectively. 5.0% NaOH solution as a precipitant was dropped slowly till the pH value was kept at 9.5. After stirred for 2h, the solid was separated by filtration, then dried at 80°C overnight and calcined at 300°C for 3h. The powdery catalysts prepared were labeled as Pd/K-OMS-2, Pd/Pb-OMS-2and Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3, respectively. 2.2 Characterization The phase identification and crystalline structure analysis were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Panalytical X'Pert PRO X-Ray diffractometer with high-intensity Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.54060Å). The chemical shift, valence of element and Pd content on surface were studied by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) in a Perkin-Elmer PHI 1600 ESCA system with Mg Kα X-ray radiation (1253.6eV, 250W). The bulk chemical composition of the samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) on a Perkin Elmer ELAN DRC-e. Solid samples were dissolved in the mixture of HCl and HNO3, and then diluted with ultrapure water. H2-TPR experiments were performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. Each sample (50mg of fresh catalyst) was pretreated at 300°C for 0.5h and subsequently cooled to ambient temperature under an Ar flow (30mL/min). Then, a 10% H2-95% Ar flow (30mL/min) was passed over the catalyst bed by heating at a rate of 10°C/min up to 900°C. Finally, the catalyst was cooled under an Ar flow (30mL/min). The consumption of H2 was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of the samples were obtained using a FEI Tecnai G20 electron microscope operated at an accelerating voltage of 200kV with an energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDXA) system. 2.3 Activity test The oxidative carbonylation reaction was performed in a 250mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer. A typical reaction condition was as follows: phenol 47g (0.5mol), tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) 1g (3mmol) and Pd (in the catalyst) 0.9mmol were introduced into the autoclave. Then the autoclave was sealed and heated up to 65°C. Subsequently, the gas mixture of CO and O2 (CO/O2 =12/1 molar ratio) was charged. The conditions employed in this procedure fell within the flammability range of CO in O2. After the reaction sustained at the pressure of 4.8MPa, the autoclave was cooled and the products were taken out every 2h. The reaction products were quantified by a capillary gas chromatography with a FID detector and a SE-54 capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of supported palladium catalysts Fig. 1 describes the DPC yields of different supported palladium catalysts and also shows that the DPC yields increase in the order of Pd/OMS-2<Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 <Pd/Pb-OMS-2. Further the DPC yields for all the catalysts increased slightly when the oxidative carbonylation reaction extended up to 22h. The majority of catalysts was inefficient and could be deemed of deactivated. Moreover, the Pd/OMS-2 catalyst is found to be deactivated much faster than the other two supported catalysts. The DPC yields of Pd/OMS-2 catalyst almost remained constant after 10h reaction, while the DPC yields of Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalyst continued to increase from 39.8% to 51.2% when reacted from 10h to 24h. To find out the causes of fast deactivation of supported palladium catalysts, a comprehensive experimental study was planned and utilizing various characterization techniques the causes were explored. 3.2 Structure stability of supported palladium catalysts XRD patterns of fresh and used supported palladium catalysts are represented in Fig. 2 . Based on the literature and our past research [18–20], the XRD patterns of Pd/OMS-2 catalyst, Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalyst and Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 catalyst correspond well to the cryptomelane-type phase of K2-xMn8O16(JCPDS 44-1386), the hollandite-type phase of Pb2-xMn8O16 (JCPDS 42-1349) and the perovskite-type phase of La0.5Pb0.5MnO3(JCPDS 22-1123) respectively. Fig. 2(a) and 2(b) shows that no peak shift is observed for the Pd/OMS-2 catalyst, but its peak intensity at 2θ=28.7°, 37.5° weakens. As illustrated in Fig. 2(c)–2(f), the crystal structures of the Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalyst and the Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 catalyst remain original structure before and after the reaction. Noticeably, no additional peaks related to active palladium species appear in any of the catalysts, indicating that the palladium species is well-dispersed on the surface of supports. The structure stability of the supported palladium catalysts was analyzed using TEM images. Fig. 3 (a) relates to the fresh Pd/OMS-2 catalyst and demonstrates that highly dispersed palladium species with particle (size of about 3nm) is loaded onto the OMS-2 nanorod supports. Fig. 3(b) relates to the used Pd/OMS-2 nanorod catalysts and demonstrates that catalysts are covered with membrane-like compounds which contain a large amount of carbon element as determined by EDXA analysis. This is consistent with the weakening of its diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns caused by the embedding of carbon on the surface. It is important that the active palladium species seems to have disappeared on the surface of OMS-2 nanorod supports. The palladium species also drops off of the surface of Pd/Pb-OMS-2 nanorod catalysts similar to the Pd/OMS-2 nanorod catalysts (Fig. 3(c) and 3(d)). Further Fig. 3(e) and 3(f) shows that Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 catalysts look rather spongy due to a fast release of a large amount of gas in the decomposition of the reacting precursors. Unfortunately, the palladium species could not be distinguished in both fresh and used Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 catalysts. The above TEM images reveal that part of the palladium species broke away from the catalyst carrier and this precisely indicates that leaching can occur in oxidative carbonylation reaction. Thus, leaching is an important deactivation cause of supported palladium catalysts. In order to explore whether palladium leaching results in the deactivation, we conducted a verification test. 3.3 Palladium leaching The palladium content of the fresh and used supported catalysts was measured by ICP-AES analysis and the results are listed in Table 1 . The data clearly indicate palladium leaching occurs during an oxidative carbonylation reaction. Pd loss ratio is 6.2%, 9.1% and 35.0% for Pd/OMS-2, Pd/Pb-OMS-2 and Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 catalysts, respectively. Because there is a serious palladium leaching, Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalyst was selected as only target and their parameters that influence the palladium leaching were then explored and are summarized in Table 2 . It is clear from the data that the solvent and oxygen atmosphere have a significant impact on the palladium leaching (Table 2, entries 7∼9) [21]. The palladium content in solution reached 3.51% for DCM and 8.90% for DMF (Table 2, entries 8∼9). At O2 atmosphere (Table 2, entries 7), 8.73% of the total palladium amount removed from the catalyst and were found in solution compared to only 0.13% under CO and O2 mixed atmosphere (Table 2, entries 1). While the amount of Pd leaching at CO+O2 atmosphere is much the same as that at air atmosphere (Table 2, entry 6). Thus, the palladium leaching is attributed to the presence of O2, not CO. Reaction temperature has little bearing on palladium leaching, and the palladium contents in solution dangle just below 1% at different temperatures (Table 2, entries 1∼5). We verified that the leached palladium was not a catalytically active species by the hot filtration test. Hot filtration tests were conducted after running the normal 4h reaction and then the solid catalysts were filtered under hot conditions [22]. The composition of the filtrate was monitored in the same reaction environment to determine the DPC yield in the absence of the supported palladium catalyst. As shown in Table 1, all catalysts in this study showed no activity after the hot filtration test. The reaction never proceeded in the filtrate without the supported palladium catalyst and a slight decline of DPC yields suggests that the DPC is being hydrolyzed instead of generation. Further, SH-HZSM-5 was added into the reactor and the corresponding DPC yield was 11.6%, compared to 12.1% without SH-HZSM-5 under the same condition [23,24]. The results indicate that the leached palladium species is not active. 3.4 Reduction and aggregation of active palladium species Both homogeneous and heterogeneous palladium catalyst are reported to be active in an oxidative carbonylation of phenol [12]. Palladium species that leached into the solution became inactive which clearly indicates that palladium species may be transforming into reduced state. XPS analysis is required to obtain the information on the reduction degree of palladium species. The XPS spectra in Fig. 4 show a peak at 335.5eV characteristic of Pd(0) and the other peak at 337.2eV corresponding to Pd(II). The binding energies of the entire used supported palladium catalysts shift toward lower binding energies as compared to the fresh catalysts, indicating the reduction of active Pd(II) species to Pd(0). As shown in Fig. 4, the initial valency of palladium could have impact on the DPC yield. The initial valency of Pd species is two in Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalysts (Fig. 4(c)), which shows the best catalytic activity. In contrast, since a large amount of Pd(0) exists in Pd/OMS-2 catalysts (Fig. 4(a)), the DPC yield is the lowest and the deactivation is the fastest among all the catalysts. A pre-reduction experiment was used to further ensure that the reduction of palladium can deactivate the catalyst. The fresh Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalyst was then reduced with formaldehyde (Fig. 1s). Results show that the catalytic activity sharply reduced and the DPC yield was just 0.31%. Take Pd/OMS-2 catalyst as a model to investigate the aggregation of palladium species. Fig. 5 (a), (b) and (c) manifest that no XRD peaks of Pd(0) or Pd(II) appear in the fresh Pd/OMS-2 catalyst when calcined at 300°C, indicating that calcination time can not affect the aggregation of palladium species. After treating at 400°C, the catalyst showed an XRD peak at 33. 9°(Fig. 5(d)), which corresponds well to the 101 plane of Pd(II) (JCPDS 43-1024) and indicates that high calcination temperature prompted the reunion of Pd(II) on the surface. As illustrated in Fig. 5(e), the aggregation of Pd(II) also occurred in the used catalyst. Besides the peak of Pd(II) species, the spectra shows an additional peak at 40.1°, which corresponds with the character of metal Pd(111)(JCPDS 46-1403). The aggregation of Pd(0) and Pd(II) hindered the re-oxidation of palladium, which is another deactivation cause of the catalyst. 3.5 The change of oxygen species Our research findings have demonstrated that oxygen species played an important role in the redox cycle of palladium species [18], so the change of oxygen species for the fresh and used catalysts were described by H2-TPR profiles (Fig. 6 ) and XPS spectra (Fig. 7 ). In the H2-TPR profiles of Pd/OMS-2 and Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalysts three reduction peaks could be deconvoluted according to the literature [25]. The α reduction peak can be possibly attributed to the reduction of surface oxygen species. The β and γ reduction peaks stand for the reduction processes of Mn4+ →Mn3+ →Mn2+. Fig. 6 (a) and (c) shows that the reduction peaks of Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalysts shift to the high temperature regions relative to that of Pd/OMS-2. It may be due to the higher Pb-O bond energy than MnO2, the present of Pb-O bonds in the Mn-O-Pb makes the mobility of the oxygen atoms in the octahedral crystal slow. The addition of the lead weakens the bulk redox ability of the OMS-2. For the La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 catalysts, each H2-TPR profiles exhibit two reduction peaks. The first peak is located at 150∼250°C and the other is positioned at 250∼380°C. The reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ occurs in the first process, and the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ occurs in the second process. Fig. 6 shows that the reduction peaks of the entire used catalyst shift to higher temperature regions in comparison to that of the fresh catalyst, implying that the Mn4+ reduces and low valence Mn3+ and Mn2+ increase for the used catalysts. The average manganese valence decreases after reaction, which leads to the weakening of redox ability [18]. A significant shift is observed for the Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalyst during reaction process, so the corresponding redox ability reflects fully in catalytic cycle of active palladium species. As shown in Fig. 7, the oxygen species derived from fitted O1s spectra was also divided into two groups: surface oxygen (Os, 531.7V) and lattice oxygen (OL, 528.7eV). From the peak area of three sets of catalysts, it can be inferred that the lattice oxygen species reduces when catalysts are used. This is consistent with the change of manganese valence. When the lattice oxygen species reduced, the low valence manganese increased for charge equilibrium. It can be inferred that the oxygen species, especially lattice oxygen, take part in the regeneration of reduced Pd (0) in the catalytic redox cycle. This is because surface oxygen is under-coordinated so that it is less reduced than that in lattice. Thus, the catalytic performance of fresh Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalyst which more lattice oxygen reduced is superior over the other two catalysts. 3.6 Possible deactivation cause of supported palladium catalyst From the results of these tests, possible deactivation causes of supported palladium catalysts can be proposed: Palladium leaching and reduction is the main cause of catalyst deactivation. Active palladium species binds to outer-most oxygen atom to form Pd-O bonds through strong interaction. Presence of higher number of Pd(II) species leads to higher interaction between Pd and O species and this makes the leaching of palladium difficult in case of Pd/Pb-OMS-2 catalysts. However, lower palladium leaching for Pd/OMS-2 catalyst in spite of less Pd(II) species founded in Fig. 3 (b), may be due to coating of carbonaceous pollution on the catalyst. Further, the leached palladium is not catalytically active species. Meanwhile, Pd(II) reduced to Pd(0) with the concomitant formation of DPC during the reaction. In order to regenerate the catalytic cycle, the formed Pd(0) species needs to be re-oxidized to Pd(II) species. Oxygen species in catalysts is effective to regenerate reduced Pd(0) in catalytic redox cycle. Apart from causes mentioned above, the carbonaceous pollution can also lead to catalyst deactivation. OMS-2 has excellent hydrophobicity and strong affinity for organic compounds [26]. Surface bonded OH groups on OMS-2 increases the adsorption of phenolic compounds. In oxidative carbonylation reaction, organic reactants are absorbed on the surface of the Pd/OMS-2 catalyst and impeded the contact between reactants and active species. 4 Conclusions Supported palladium catalysts were found to be deactivated in less than 22h during oxidative carbonylation of phenol and the deactivation causes have been studied. The structure stability of Pd/OMS-2, Pd/Pb-OMS-2 and Pd/La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 catalysts were found to be good in reaction environment. The main deactivation causes are leaching and reduction of the palladium species. During the course of reaction, the palladium was partially leached into the solution and experimental analysis has confirmed that the leached palladium was not catalytically active species. Due to reduction in the amount of lattice oxygen, the redox ability of supports to regenerate Pd(II) was reduced and more Pd(0) formed resulting in the loss of catalytic activity. Acknowledgement We are grateful for the financial support from Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Process Ministry of Education (Grant No.GCP201301) and Hubei Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No.2013CFB322). The authors also thank the Hubei Provincial Department of Education (Grant No.Q20131503), the Opening Project of Hubei Key Laboratory of Lipid Chemistry and Nutrition (201505) and Wuhan Institute of Technology (Grant No.10112061) for their supports. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.07.028. coredata.dc:description: Palladium catalysts supported on manganese oxides octahedral molecular sieves (OMS-2), Pb doped OMS-2 (Pb-OMS-2) and perovskite-type La0.5Pb0.5MnO3 were prepared for investigating the deactivation causes of catalysts during the oxidative carbonylation of phenol. The catalytic experiments on three different sets of catalysts demonstrated that they were inactive after continuous reaction for 22h. XRD patterns and HRTEM images demonstrated that carbonaceous pollution and palladium leaching occurred during the reaction process. The solvent and oxygen have significant impact on the palladium leaching by ICP-AES analysis. In addition, hot filtration tests and SH-HZSM-5 adsorption studies indicated that the leached palladium species are not active species. The results of XPS patterns and H2-TPR profiles showed that aggregation and reduction of Pd species was another deactivation cause. It was discovered that lattice oxygen species decreased and palladium aggregated, which hindered the re-oxidation of Pd(0) to Pd(II). In summary, carbonaceous pollution, Pd leaching, aggregation and consumption of oxygen species hindered the redox recycling of palladium, which resulted in the deactivation of supported palladium catalysts for the oxidative carbonylation of phenol.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation causes of supported palladium catalysts for the oxidative carbonylation of phenol
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
